2.title: Eliezer Yudkowsky
2.clickbait: Cofounder, with Nick Bostrom, of the field of value alignment theory.

42.title: Nearest unblocked strategy
42.clickbait: If you patch an agent's preference framework to avoid an undesirable solution, what can you expect to happen?

48.title: Patch resistance
48.clickbait: One does not simply solve the value alignment problem.

178.title: Arbital "tag" relationship
178.clickbait: Tags are a way to connect pages that share a common topic.

370.editSummary: reflecting the fact that we only have one type of mark now.
370.title: Arbital mark
370.clickbait: What is a mark on Arbital? When is it created? Why is it important?

597.title: Arbital page clickbait
597.clickbait: The text you are reading right now is clickbait.

10g.title: Instrumental convergence
10g.clickbait: Some strategies can help achieve most possible simple goals.  E.g., acquiring more computing power or more material resources.  By default, unless averted, we can expect advanced AIs to do that.

17b.title: Arbital lens
17b.clickbait: A lens is a page that presents another page's content from a different angle.

1cv.title: AI safety mindset
1cv.clickbait: Asking how AI designs could go wrong, instead of imagining them going right.

1g4.title: Epistemic exclusion
1g4.clickbait: How would you build an AI that, no matter what else it learned about the world, never knew or wanted to know what was inside your basement?

1ln.editSummary: alias. note to self: come back and explain new requisites system.
1ln.title: Arbital requisites
1ln.clickbait: To understand a thing you often need to understand some other things.

1rt.title: Arbital path
1rt.clickbait: Arbital path is a linear sequence of pages tailored specifically to teach a given concept to a user.

2mx.title: Open subproblems in aligning a Task-based AGI
2mx.clickbait: Open research problems, especially ones we can model today, in building an AGI that can "paint all cars pink" without turning its future light cone into pink-painted cars.

2v.title: AI alignment
2v.clickbait: The great civilizational problem of creating artificially intelligent computer systems such that running them is a good idea.

2x.title: Omnipotence test for AI safety
2x.clickbait: Would your AI produce disastrous outcomes if it suddenly gained omnipotence and omniscience? If so, why did you program something that *wants* to hurt you and is held back only by lacking the power?

2x4.title: Niceness is the first line of defense
2x4.clickbait: The *first* line of defense in dealing with any partially superhuman AI system advanced enough to possibly be dangerous is that it does not *want* to hurt you or defeat your safety measures.

2xd.title: Shutdown problem
2xd.clickbait: How to build an AGI that lets you shut it down, despite the obvious fact that this will interfere with whatever the AGI's goals are.

3d.title: Arbital
3d.clickbait: Arbital is the place for crowdsourced, intuitive math explanations.

3hs.title: Author's guide to Arbital
3hs.clickbait: How to write intuitive, flexible content on Arbital.

3n.title: Arbital "parent" relationship
3n.clickbait: Parent-child relationship between pages implies a strong, inseparable connection.

41l.title: Superintelligent
41l.clickbait: A "superintelligence" is strongly superhuman (strictly higher-performing than any and all humans) on every cognitive problem.

4m.title: AI alignment open problem
4m.clickbait: Tag for open problems under AI alignment.

6w.title: Task-directed AGI
6w.clickbait: An advanced AI that's meant to pursue a series of limited-scope goals given it by the user.  In Bostrom's terminology, a Genie.

6z.title: Boxed AI
6z.clickbait: Idea: what if we limit how AI can interact with the world. That'll make it safe, right??

7fx.title: Directing, vs. limiting, vs. opposing
7fx.clickbait: Getting the AI to compute the right action in a domain; versus getting the AI to not compute at all in an unsafe domain; versus trying to prevent the AI from acting successfully.  (Prefer 1 & 2.)

7g0.title: Non-adversarial principle
7g0.clickbait: At no point in constructing an Artificial General Intelligence should we construct a computation that tries to hurt us, and then try to stop it from hurting us.
7g0.text:
The 'Non-Adversarial Principle' is a proposed design principle for [sufficiently_advanced_AI sufficiently advanced Artificial Intelligence] stating that, by design, the human operators and the AGI should never come into conflict.  Special cases of this principle include [2x4] and [ai_wants_security].

Ultimately, every event inside an AI--every RAM access and CPU instruction--is an event set in motion by our own design.  Even if the AI is modifying its code, the modified code is a causal outcome of the original code.  There is no reason why we should ever construct an algorithm that is trying to hurt us.  If we write code that is searching for a way to hurt us, we've already done something silly--we've willfully shot ourselves in the foot.

According to this principle, if the AI has an off-switch, our first thought should not be, 'How do we have guards with guns defending this off-switch so the AI can't destroy it?' but 'How do we make sure the AI *wants* this off-switch to exist?'  If we think the AI is not ready to act on the Internet, our first thought should not be 'How do we [airgapping airgap] the AI to prevent it from getting on the Internet?' but 'How do we construct an AI that wouldn't *try* to do anything on the Internet after it got access?'

Under the [agents_as_searches] view, we can see an AI as embodying computations that search out actions within a domain.  The [nonadversarial_principle non-adversarial principle] then says that we should not be running a computation which is *searching* for ways to hurt us.

That is:  Suppose you don't want the AI to go on the Internet.  If your first imagined measure is [airgapping airgapping] the AI's hardware from the Internet or otherwise [ai_boxing boxing the AI], then what you're trying to do is ensure that *a computation searching for ways to reach the Internet returns a null result.*  But why are you running this computation in the first place?  Rather than our primary strategy being to have this computation return an empty set as its result, our primary strategy should be to have this computation not run at all.  (E.g., because the Internet is not an [whitelisting operator-whitelisted] domain.)

If our primary strategy is "have the search algorithm come up empty", then we need to worry that the AI's search [9f considers some class of strategies we didn't imagine]; we are pitting our own wits against a potentially [9f weird] or [41l superhuman] search.  But leaving aside the danger that our own wits aren't sufficient, we just shouldn't be putting an AI in a box and then having the AI search for ways to get out of the box.  This is just the wrong thing to do with computing power, we have written the wrong code.  Our design has already failed *if that search ever runs,* not after the search computation finds a way out of the box.  If you're building a toaster, you don't build one element that heats the toast and another element that cools down the toast.

So if you include a [2xd shutdown switch], you should also make sure that the AI *wants* there to be a shutdown switch; that the AI *wants* the state of this shutdown switch to reflect the dynamic decisions of the human operators; that the AI does not *want* to influence the operators to press the switch or not press it; and that the AI does *not* want to cause anything besides an orderly suspend-to-disk to happen after this switch is pressed.  There should not be a *running computation* that is searching for ways to influence the switch event, or searching for ways to ensure that other goals are achieved even after the switch is pressed.

*After* we ensure that computation is not running in the first place, we can think about a fallback line of defense: like shutting down electricity to the server room if the shutdown switch fails to operate, or ways to isolate the AI from other computers to prevent it from constructing a subagent that goes on operating after the shutdown button is pressed.  But the *plan* is not that the AI tries to do these things and we successfully prevent the attempt; the plan is that the AI doesn't try.  If we imagine the AI trying to prevent shutdown, we ought to [rule_of_surprise feel very surprised in our imagination].  If the AI actually does try,  we should be crying 'What?' and tracking down which strong-seeming assumption has failed.

Similarly, we should probably still airgap the AI from the Internet, as opposed to saying, "Oh, but the AI is designed to be safe!" and sauntering blithely on.  But that doesn't mean we *rely* on the airgap.  Nuclear power plants have concrete containment units in case the core melts down; but the *design* is not that they melt down, the *plan* doesn't say "And then on Tuesday the core melts down, but that's fine because of the containment unit."  By design, that big concrete shell isn't supposed to actually be necessary, ever.  And then we build it anyway, because lol plans.

Similarly, when designing an AI, we should pretend that the airgap doesn't exist or that the AI will [2x suddenly get Internet access anyway] on Tuesday, and as our primary measure design the AI to be safe under those circumstances.  And *then* we add the airgap.  The plan doesn't call for the airgap to ever matter, but we put it in anyway because lol plans.

More generally:  No aspect of the AI's design should ever put us in an adversarial position vis-a-vis the AI, or pit the AI's wits against our wits.  If this happens it means the design has failed.

See also:

- [2x4]
- [2x]
- [align_limit_oppose]

7g1.title: Sufficiently advanced Artificial Intelligence
7g1.clickbait: 'Sufficiently advanced Artificial Intelligences' are AIs with enough 'advanced agent properties' that we start needing to do 'AI alignment' to them.

7g2.title: You can't get the coffee if you're dead
7g2.clickbait: An AI given the goal of 'get the coffee' can't achieve that goal if it has been turned off; so even an AI whose goal is just to fetch the coffee may try to avert a shutdown button being pressed.

7tb.title: The AI must tolerate your safety measures
7tb.clickbait: A corollary of the nonadversarial principle is that "The AI must tolerate your safety measures."

7td.title: Generalized principle of cognitive alignment
7td.clickbait: When we're asking how we want the AI to think about an alignment problem, one source of inspiration is trying to have the AI mirror our own thoughts about that problem.

7v8.title: Principles in AI alignment
7v8.clickbait: A 'principle' of AI alignment is a very general design goal like 'understand what the heck is going on inside the AI' that has informed a wide set of specific design proposals.

9f.title: Cognitive uncontainability
9f.clickbait: 'Cognitive uncontainability' is when we can't hold all of an agent's possibilities inside our own minds.
